author: By Michael Levenson
title: As protests against police violence surge, Florida passes a bill to combat ‘public disorder.’
description: Critics call the measure racist and anti-democratic, and say it could criminalize peaceful demonstrations.
content: The Republican-led Florida Senate on Thursday passed a bill that was intended to crack down on rioting, but that critics said would criminalize the peaceful demonstrations against police brutality that have swept across the state and the country since the killing of George Floyd last year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Agony of Pandemic Parenting
description: A single mother in Spokane, Wash., opens up about what it’s really been like to raise a child over the past year.
content: This episode contains strong language and emotional descriptions about the challenges of being a parent during the pandemic, so if your young child is with you, you might want to listen later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: As N.Y. Courts Seek to Root Out Racism, a Clerk Is Heard Using a Slur
description: A lawyer for a teenager said he overheard racist comments directed at his client during a hearing in New York Family Court. The incident came months after a judge warned about racism in the courts.
content: At the end of an hourlong virtual hearing in Family Court in Manhattan on Thursday, Holden E. Thornhill’s 15-year-old client, who is Black, stood up to alert the authorities at his detention facility that the hearing had finished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Garland lifts Trump-era curb on use of consent decrees to overhaul police forces.
description: The move by the attorney general comes as the Justice Department prepares to step up its role in investigating allegations of racist and illegal behavior by police forces.
content: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland on Friday rescinded a Trump administration policy that curbed the use of consent decrees to address police misconduct, as the Justice Department prepares to step up its role in investigating allegations of racist and illegal behavior by police forces amid a nationwide outcry about the deaths of Black people at the hands of officers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Booster shots and re-vaccinations could be needed. Drug companies are planning for it.
description: Pfizer’s chief executive said a third dose of the company’s Covid-19 vaccine was “likely” to be needed within a year of the initial two-dose inoculation, followed by annual vaccinations.
content: Scientists have long said that giving people a single course of a Covid-19 vaccine might not be sufficient in the long term, and that booster shots and even annual vaccinations might prove necessary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
description: Explore future worlds or get lost in a time loop with these options.
content: Filmmaking had barely been invented and already it was venturing into science fiction: One of the most famous early movies is Georges Méliès’s “A Trip to the Moon,” from 1902.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Biden’s approval rating rises, helped by the vaccine distribution push.
description: Americans don’t think the president deserves sole credit for the widespread availability of Covid vaccines, but they like the job he’s doing getting them distributed, a new poll found.
content: The American public doesn’t think President Biden deserves sole credit for the widespread availability of Covid-19 vaccines, but it overwhelmingly likes the job he’s doing getting them distributed — and it’s feeding a high job approval rating over all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: With a new C.D.C. panel meeting set, the J.&J. vaccine pause will likely last at least another week.
description: The advisory panel will discuss safety data related to a small number of blood-clotting cases in Johnson & Johnson vaccine recipients. It is unclear whether the vaccine was responsible for the clots.
content: The federal government’s call for a pause on using Johnson & Johnson’s Covid-19 vaccine could last at least another week, further complicating efforts by federal and state health officials to reschedule appointments, and reassure jittery Americans that the vaccine is safe and effective.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: New in Paperback: ‘Until the End of Time’ and ‘Warhol’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: SQUARE HAUNTING: Five Writers in London Between the Wars, by Francesca Wade. (Crown, 432 pp., $18.) Bloomsbury’s Mecklenburgh Square was home to five pioneering feminists across 25 years: the poet H.D., the novelist Dorothy Sayers, the medievalist Eileen Power, the classicist Jane Ellen Harrison and, famously, Virginia Woolf. Our reviewer, Blanche Wiesen Cook, called Wade’s portrait of the group “enchanting.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Joye Hummel, First Woman to Write Wonder Woman, Dies at 97
description: For almost 70 years, her contributions to one of the comic-book world’s most enduring characters went largely unappreciated.
content: Joye Hummel Murchison Kelly was the first woman to write scripts for the Wonder Woman comic-book franchise, but hardly anyone was aware of that for almost 70 years. Then Jill Lepore tracked her down while writing her 2014 book, “The Secret History of Wonder Woman,” and suddenly Ms. Hummel was a cause célèbre in the fan universe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: What Will Happen to All the Empty Office Buildings and Hotels?
description: Commercial real estate has been hit hard by the pandemic, but there are plans to convert some of the now empty spaces into apartment buildings.
content: Dark windows. Quiet lobbies. Hushed halls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: The End of the United States’ Forever War
description: A new book about the Pech Valley in Afghanistan’s violent east offers poignant lessons as the Biden administration announces plans to withdraw all troops.
content: You’re reading this week’s At War newsletter. Sign up here to get it delivered to your inbox every Friday. Email us at atwar@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: What to Know About the Police Shooting of Adam Toledo
description: Body camera footage showed that a Chicago officer fired a single shot into the boy’s chest after chasing him down a dark alley.
content: Officials in Chicago released body camera footage on Thursday of a police officer fatally shooting a 13-year-old boy last month, setting off protests over the use of deadly force by police in a city that has been beleaguered by violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Rhubarb Cobbler Where the Sweet-Tart Flavors Sing
description: Roasting sugared rhubarb until the juices condense into a tangy syrup makes for the best possible spring dessert.
content: Some cobblers are like cake: neatly sliceable, with bits of soft fruit strewn in the crumb. Others are more like pie, with a jammy compote sandwiched between two flaky crusts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and David E. Sanger
title: President Biden and the Japanese prime minister pledge new partnership to advance ‘shared democratic norms.’
description: President Biden welcomed Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga of Japan to the White House on Friday, using the first visit by a foreign leader during his presidency to underscore the importance of America’s allies as the United States confronts an increasingly aggressive China.
content: President Biden welcomed Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga of Japan to the White House on Friday, using the first visit by a foreign leader during his presidency to underscore the importance of America’s allies as the United States confronts an increasingly aggressive China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | April 21, 2021
description: How long until electric vehicles rule the road in the United States?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anahad O'Connor
title: Gearing Up for the ‘New Normal’
description: In “The New Normal,” Dr. Jennifer Ashton explores the mental health repercussions of the pandemic and ways to rebuild our overall health.
content: As the chief medical correspondent for ABC News, Dr. Jennifer Ashton has spent the past year helping to make sense of the pandemic for the network’s millions of viewers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: In Russia, a Military Buildup That Can’t be Missed
description: Russia’s massing of tanks and infantry along its southwestern border with Ukraine was meant to send a message, analysts say.
content: MASLOVKA, Russia — Deep in a pine forest in southern Russia, military trucks, their silhouettes blurred by camouflage netting, appear through the trees. Soldiers in four-wheel-drive vehicles creep along rutted dirt roads. And outside a newly pitched tent camp, sentries, Kalashnikovs slung over their shoulders, pace back and forth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Grode
title: Head of New York Theater Workshop to Depart in 2022
description: James C. Nicola, who balanced provocative programming with shows aimed at Broadway, will have served 34 years as artistic director.
content: As the New York theater world points toward reopening, one major force within its nonprofit sector — and a central figure in its often lucrative collaborations with Broadway — is preparing to walk away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Books About Racism and Police Violence Fill Out List of ‘Most Challenged’ Titles
description: After a year dominated by protests against police killings of Black Americans, the books on the list of the most frequently challenged titles of 2020 reflected the movement — and the backlash to it.
content: When the American Library Association released its list of the 10 most frequently banned or challenged books of 2020, it was no surprise to Angie Thomas that her debut novel, “The Hate U Give,” had made its return to the list for a third appearance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Kimmel Heckles ‘Future Former Florida Congressman’ Matt Gaetz
description: Kimmel poked fun at Gaetz and his friend Joel Greenberg for making their Venmo transactions public: “One of those ‘salads’ cost more than $1,000 — I guess they added avocado.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Loos
title: Art of the Dealer: Paula Cooper Shores Up Her Legacy
description: She opened the first gallery in SoHo and was a part of Chelsea’s initial wave. Now, at 83, the dean of ‘tough art’ will bring in new partners and start a year-round branch in Palm Beach.
content: In her first show at Paula Cooper Gallery in Chelsea, the painter Cecily Brown showed a large triptych, “A Day! Help! Help! Another Day!” (2016). The 33-foot-wide work, which draws its title from an Emily Dickinson poem, was an energetic field of colorful marks typical of Brown’s expressionistic style.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Arlo the Alligator Boy’ Review: Of Songs and Scales
description: This hyperactive animated Netflix musical for kids, with messages of empowerment and references to “Midnight Cowboy,” has a lot on its plate.
content: A tiger, a miniature Italian man, a girl with gigantism, a fish with legs, a pink hairball and a redheaded half-reptile walk into Manhattan. That’s the setup of “Arlo the Alligator Boy,” a hyperactive cartoon musical intended for kids on Netflix. The punchline is that the streaming service has already greenlighted a spinoff about this chipper green tyke for a 20-episode series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: The Lost Embryos
description: Elaine Meyer and Barry Prizant had given up on having more than one child. Then, in their 60s, they got a letter from the hospital where they’d long ago had IVF treatment.
content: When the first letter from Women & Infants Hospital arrived in the mail in July 2017, Elaine Meyer thought perhaps it was a fund-raising solicitation or clerical error. The letter, which included a billing invoice, addressed her as “Dear Patient,” but she had not been a patient at the hospital for nearly two decades. That’s when she and her husband, Barry Prizant, had completed their infertility treatment there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz and Alicia Parlapiano
title: Why the Vaccine Safety Numbers Are Still Fuzzy
description: Putting a risk in context: The rate of blood clots is extremely low, but the pause in the Johnson & Johnson vaccine could reveal more cases.
content: When federal officials paused administration of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine after six cases of a rare clotting disorder, one fatal, among the 6.9 million people who had received the vaccine, many critics noted that the chance of a serious ailment was so rare as to be negligible — less frequent than being struck by lightning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: Nature and Nurture: 8 Picture Books for Earth Day
description: Andrea Wang, Jason Chin, Travis Jonker, Grant Snider, Juana Martinez-Neal, Corinna Luyken and more depict our symbiotic relationship with the environment.
content: LALA’S WORDSWritten and illustrated by Gracey Zhang
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Democrats running in down-ballot races helped Biden win votes in conservative areas, a study finds.
description: President Biden, who eked out a 12,000-vote victory in Georgia, received a small but potentially important boost from the state’s conservative areas if at least one local Democrat was running in a down-ballot race, according to a new study by Run for Something, an organization dedicated to recruiting and supporting liberal candidates. That finding extended even to the state’s reddest districts.
content: President Biden, who eked out a 12,000-vote victory in Georgia, received a small but potentially important boost from the state’s conservative areas if at least one local Democrat was running in a down-ballot race, according to a new study by Run for Something, an organization dedicated to recruiting and supporting liberal candidates. That finding extended even to the state’s reddest districts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Ellis
title: Minnesota Values White Comfort More Than Black Lives
description: As I walk around my hometown, I see so many boarded up buildings. Who is really being protected?
content: MINNEAPOLIS — The morning the murder trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with killing George Floyd, began, I was visiting my mom at a hospital just blocks from the courthouse. I remember noting that it was unseasonably warm for late March in this part of the Midwest. But that wasn’t the most striking part of the day. Nor was the long line of satellite trucks or the reporters from around the world surrounding the Hennepin County Government Center. Instead, what gave me pause was all the plywood that encased the ground floor of the hospital’s emergency department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: A Battle of Boos and Cheers at the Symphony
description: In the early 1980s, John Adams’s “Grand Pianola Music” defied the seriousness of classical music. Not everyone liked that.
content: It was 1970, and the composer John Adams was tripping on LSD.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Katie Rogers
title: Biden and Suga Agree U.S. and Japan Will Work Together on 5G
description: The subtext of the meeting was responding to China’s influence and its aggressive actions in the Indo-Pacific and beyond, and Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga resisted being drawn into a rivalry.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden and Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga of Japan pledged on Friday to work jointly on the rapid development of 5G communications technologies to prevent one of China’s leading companies from dominating the global market, a symbolic first move at shoring up an alliance that withered during the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: The global death toll from Covid-19 is nearing 3 million.
description: The number of confirmed coronavirus cases has surged to nearly 140 million as dangerous virus variants spread and countries race to provide enough vaccines.
content: The world’s Covid-19 death toll is approaching yet another once unthinkable number — nearly three million people have died from the virus since the first cases surfaced more than 14 months ago and upended life for people across the globe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr, Amy Lynch and Sarah Mervosh
title: Family members were waiting for news at a nearby hotel.
description: More than 12 hours after a gunman killed eight people at a FedEx facility in Indianapolis, officials have not yet identified the victims.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — Families of people who work at the FedEx facility in Indianapolis continued to gather at a Holiday Inn Express & Suites on Friday, waiting in anguished suspense for news about their loved ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: A writer gives an update on her husband’s struggle with Covid-19.
content: A year into the pandemic, many of us are looking back to make sense of what happened, or searching for lessons as we slowly begin to emerge from the struggles of the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Mother of Tamir Rice, a 12-year-old killed by the police, asks D.O.J. to reopen its investigation.
description: The request to Attorney General Merrick B. Garland comes after he and President Biden vowed to use the powers of the federal government to fight racial injustice.
content: The family of Tamir Rice, a 12-year-old boy who was shot and killed in 2014 by the Cleveland police, has asked Attorney General Merrick B. Garland to reopen the Justice Department’s investigation into the shooting, which was closed in December after the department said it could not charge the officers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Indianapolis, Refugees, Boba Tea: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samuel L. Myers Jr
title: Minnesota Is One of the Best Places to Live in America. Unless You’re Black.
description: The state’s reputation belies some of the country’s largest racial disparities.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Minnesota is one of the best places to live in America. It has good schools, excellent housing and low unemployment. It regularly appears near the top of indexes for livability. But all of that matters much less if you’re Black.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Liberty University Sues Jerry Falwell Jr., Alleging Deception
description: The lawsuit claims that Mr. Falwell, the university’s former president, withheld scandalous and potentially damaging information from Liberty’s board of trustees.
content: Liberty University sued its former president Jerry Falwell Jr. this week, exacerbating the messy divorce between the Christian university and the leader whose family name has been synonymous with the school since its founding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Sticking Point
description: Don’t skip this Friday challenge from Tom Pepper.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — There are so many action words in this Tom Pepper puzzle it’s like a comic strip — super fun to race or pick through but not easy by any means. We like to flyspeck this Friday/Saturday grid thing, and I’ll just note that when Mr. Pepper has a Saturday grid he will hit for the cycle, it’s the only day on which we haven’t solved him. I think this feels like a Friday but I’m willing to reconsider. Another Pepper trait is high-score scrabble words, and this grid is one letter short of a pangram (that letter is featured in a clue mentioned in the constructor notes, which you should read for a very cruciverbal chuckle).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: In Italy, younger people are accused of jumping the line to get the vaccine.
description: “How can people in all conscience jump the line?” Prime Minister Mario Draghi said. “Knowing that they leave exposed a person who is over 75 to a risk, a concrete risk of dying, or a fragile person?”
content: Last year, in the worst days of the pandemic in Italy, old people died in record numbers. Now, as the country rolls out its vaccination campaign, national authorities have uncovered a rash of line-cutting by younger people and accused them of depriving the elderly and the most vulnerable of their shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone, William J. Broad and Michael Crowley
title: Iran Says It Began Enriching Uranium to 60 Percent. How Important Is That?
description: A highly purified form of uranium is needed to make an atomic bomb, but the main point of Tehran’s action may be to give it leverage in nuclear talks.
content: Iran has started enriching its uranium supply to 60 percent purity — the closest the country has ever come to the level needed for a weapon — in response to the sabotage of an Iranian nuclear site last weekend linked to Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Berkman
title: ‘Do I Really Belong Here?’: Korean Americans in the N.B.A. Wonder
description: A small network of Korean Americans working throughout basketball are helping one another grow professionally and feel understood personally, while hoping to add to their ranks.
content: Early this season, Evan Scott was officiating an N.B.A. game in Portland when a member of the Trail Blazers’ coaching staff approached him during a timeout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Why Reopening Ceremonies in NYC Are So Important Right Now
description: Movie theaters, hotels, restaurants and other businesses are putting a lot of thought into the process.
content: When Coney Island reopened this month after more than a year of sickness, death and unemployment, officials wanted to make sure the ceremony hit the right tone: one of joy, but also of respect and gratitude.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: What to Know About Migrant Children in San Diego
description: Friday: Mayor Todd Gloria talks about the sheltering of young migrants at the city’s convention center.

author: By Kirthana Ramisetti
title: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love ‘Billy on the Street’
description: Filmed almost entirely outdoors in Manhattan, the gonzo game show serves as a time capsule of the city before the pandemic.
content: To live in New York City right now is to feel constantly nostalgic for the place it used to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Biden’s Supreme Court commission may weigh a range of potential changes beyond expanding seats.
description: President Biden’s commission to evaluate proposed overhauls to the Supreme Court is planning to tackle potential changes that range far beyond the hotly disputed proposal to expand the number of justices, according to people familiar with the matter.
content: President Biden’s commission to evaluate proposed overhauls to the Supreme Court is planning to tackle potential changes that range far beyond the hotly disputed proposal to expand the number of justices, according to people familiar with the matter.

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: A Family Opens Up About Its Investing Mistakes
description: The family behind the Nathan Cummings Foundation agreed four years ago to invest more of the endowment in social justice causes. In a new report, it discusses how difficult that was.
content: Families routinely struggle to make simple decisions. But when their members come from three generations and the issue involves how to invest nearly half a billion dollars, the discussions can quickly get complicated, to say the least.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe and Laura Cappelle
title: Gustavo Dudamel, Superstar Conductor, Will Lead Paris Opera
description: In a coup, the venerable company has hired as its next music director the rare classical artist to have crossed into pop-culture celebrity.
content: When Alexander Neef was named the next director of the mighty Paris Opera in 2019, he did not have a particular candidate in mind to succeed the company’s music director, who was leaving after a decade. “I felt I should consult with the musicians,” Neef said by phone recently, “and see who for them, what for them, how for them the future looked like.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: The Carpenter Who Built Tiny Homes for Toronto’s Homeless
description: Khaleel Seivwright built himself a wooden shanty while living on a West Coast commune. Then he started building similar lodgings for homeless people in Toronto to survive the winter.
content: TORONTO — On his way to work on a construction site, Khaleel Seivwright surveyed the growing number of tents lining an intercity highway and in parks with increasing discomfort. How would these people survive Toronto’s damp, frigid winters, let alone the coronavirus, which had pushed so many out of overcrowded shelters?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Love Letter: Jennifer Lopez and Alex Rodriguez Call It Quits for Real
description: And: A forbidden interfaith romance.
content: Spring cleaning season is here. And, for some, that doesn’t only apply to cluttered closets: Sometimes relationships get purged, too. (Consider it “uncuffing season”!)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: This may be the moment to make fried chicken.
content: Good morning. I’m feeling a powerful urge to cook fried chicken this weekend. Maybe the fiendishly spicy version (above) that Melissa Clark learned at the elbow of Rodney Frazer at Peaches HotHouse in Brooklyn, or the dead simple one Michael Ruhlman picked up at Wagner’s Village Inn, in southeastern Indiana.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Alison Gopnik
description: The April 16 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Alison Gopnik. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Oath Keeper Pleads Guilty and Will Cooperate in Jan. 6 Riot Inquiry
description: The plea by a member of the far-right extremist group the Oath Keepers was the first to be entered publicly by any of the more than 400 people who have been charged so far in the attack.
content: A member of the Oath Keepers militia who was charged in connection with the riot at the Capitol pleaded guilty on Friday and agreed to cooperate with the government — potentially against other members of the far-right extremist group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Helen McCrory, British Star of Stage, Film and TV, Dies at 52
description: She was acclaimed for her work on the TV series “Peaky Blinders” and in three Harry Potter movies, but she first gained notice in the London theater.
content: Helen McCrory, the accomplished and versatile British stage and screen actress who played Narcissa Malfoy in three Harry Potter films and the matriarch Polly Gray on the BBC series “Peaky Blinders,” in addition to earning critical plaudits for her stage work, has died at her home in north London. She was 52.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: Email, a Modern Expression of Passive Aggression
description: One option that is always available: embrace the petty.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: When Opposites Become Best Friends
description: Christian Hendry said Wynne Hamerman “taught me what it means to really care about people.” She says she learned from him “how to be patient.”
content: Christian Hendry said that Wynne Hamerman was a “social butterfly,” when they met at the University of Connecticut at the start of their sophomore years in September 2009.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: That Popular S.U.V. Is Going to Cost You
description: Demand plus production delays have tightened the supply of new models. That means fewer deals. The only good news? Your trade-in may get a better price.
content: Car shoppers may find that bargains are scarce this year. But better prices on trade-ins may help ease the pain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: The mayor of Indianapolis calls the shooting ‘horrific news.’
description: Mayor Joe Hogsett has pushed an initiative to highlight public safety while confronting gun violence in the city.
content: The mayor of Indianapolis on Friday described the deadly shooting at a FedEx warehouse near the city’s airport as “horrific news.” It was the latest time this year that the mayor has responded to a mass shooting that amplified gun violence in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Feeding Hate With Video
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, April 16, 2021.
content: “We realized that if we wanted a future on YouTube, it had to be driven by confrontation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Weiner
title: Chelsea Dungee Was Ready for Her W.N.B.A. (and Yacht?) Moment
description: Dungee, a guard from the University of Arkansas, was drafted fifth overall by the Dallas Wings after a whirlwind few days (that’s the yacht) and a lifetime in the gym.
content: Chelsea Dungee was flying on Thursday, the day of the W.N.B.A. draft. She wasn’t on the court, where the ambidextrous guard is used to getting airtime on both sides of the basket. She was getting on a plane, returning to Fayetteville, Ark. She was also euphoric.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Pregnant women in Britain will be offered Covid-19 vaccines.
description: Early in the pandemic, Britain had recommended against vaccines for pregnant women, citing a lack of research on side effects.
content: Pregnant women in Britain are now eligible to receive a Covid-19 vaccine, British health authorities announced on Friday, citing data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that showed that about 90,000 pregnant women had been vaccinated in the United States without any health issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Makes You Cringe?
description: An awkward conversation? A dad joke? An embarrassing photo?
content: What makes you cringe? An awkward conversation? A dad joke? Shameless self-promotion on social media? A trashy TV show? A Boomer trying to be young and hip? An old photo of yourself wearing an outdated fashion?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela L. Rasmussen
title: I’m a Virus Expert Who Got the J&J Vaccine. I’m Not Losing Sleep.
description: Here’s how to think about the federal investigation into rare but severe blood clots associated with the vaccine.
content: About a week ago, I received the Johnson & Johnson Covid-19 vaccine. It was a joyous moment, after more than a year of fear of the coronavirus. Then, on Tuesday, I had a flurry of texts from concerned family members, friends and colleagues who had recently seen the news. Health authorities had requested a pause for the Johnson & Johnson vaccine to investigate six blood clotting cases among women who had been vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘The Falcon and the Winter Soldier’ Season 1, Episode 5: Shielded
description: As the series approaches its finale, the writers took some time in the penultimate episode to reestablish their characters.
content: About halfway through this week’s “The Falcon and the Winter Soldier,” Bucky Barnes shows up in Louisiana to spend some quality time with his old colleague Sam Wilson, who is taking a break from the superhero business to help his sister fix their family’s fishing boat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Trump Is Gone, but Land Disputes Along Border Continue Under Biden
description: A Texas judge allowed the government this week to take possession of a family’s land because the Biden administration has yet to end lawsuits seeking property along the border.
content: WASHINGTON — After battling for years against the Trump administration’s plan to seize some of their family’s land in South Texas to build a border wall, the Cavazos siblings believed the inauguration of President Biden would bring a successful end to their fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter
title: Book by Officer Who Shot Breonna Taylor Is a New Test for Publishers
description: Sgt. Jonathan Mattingly, one of the officers involved in the fatal shooting, has a book deal with a small press, but its distributor, Simon & Schuster, in an unusual move, said it won’t ship it.
content: When the small, independent publisher Post Hill Press said on Thursday that it would release a book by one of the Louisville police officers who shot Breonna Taylor, the outrage practically burned down the internet. It took less than 12 hours for Simon & Schuster to announce that it would not distribute the book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Another Unlikely Pandemic Shortage: Boba Tea
description: The popular drink’s main ingredient, tapioca pearls, could soon be in short supply because of delays in unloading cargo ships from Asia.
content: A panic erupted on the West Coast this week. Over a drink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: When TV Goes Right Past Meditative to Vegetative
description: “Earth Moods” may look like a screensaver, but you’ll have to pay Disney+ to enjoy its calming effects.
content: “Earth Moods,” which landed on Disney+ on Friday, is a television show: five episodes, each 31 minutes long. So why does it look so much like a screensaver?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Williams
title: 10 Memorable Conversations From 15 Years of the Book Review’s Podcast
description: Talks with Toni Morrison, Jeanette Winterson, Reginald Dwayne Betts and others, from the eras of both the show’s hosts, Sam Tanenhaus and Pamela Paul.
content: This month we’re celebrating the 15th anniversary of the Book Review’s podcast, the first podcast at The Times and still going strong. Pamela Paul, the show’s host and the editor of the Book Review, recently wrote about 15 of her favorite episodes from the eight years she has been at the helm. I thought I would expand the scope to the entire archive — Sam Tanenhaus, Paul’s predecessor, hosted for seven years — and share 10 more memorable conversations. (As an editor at The Times, I’ve had a hand in the podcast since 2011.) Below you’ll hear Toni Morrison discuss her vision for her novel “A Mercy”; Andre Agassi, Christopher Hitchens and Jeanette Winterson talk about their memoirs; Andrew Solomon on the profound lessons of death and dying; and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: 13 Key Moments That Shaped the Trial of Derek Chauvin
description: In testimony from 45 witnesses over three weeks, attorneys returned to the trial’s central questions: what caused George Floyd’s death, and were Mr. Chauvin’s actions justified and lawful.
content: In the three weeks of the trial of Derek Chauvin, dozens of witnesses have testified; hours of video of George Floyd’s arrest have been played, paused and replayed; and two sides of the courtroom have presented opposing narratives to a jury tasked with determining the guilt or innocence of a former police officer charged with murder in one of the most watched trials in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vali R. Nasr
title: The Clock Is Ticking for Biden on Iran
description: The United States must quickly decide on lifting sanctions and come up with a credible road map for reviving the Iran nuclear deal.
content: Since early April, Iranian officials have been meeting in Vienna with British, Chinese, French, German and Russian counterparts, the remaining members of the 2015 nuclear deal that the United States abandoned in 2018. The United States is participating indirectly, with European diplomats going back and forth between the Iranians and the U.S. diplomats, led by President Biden’s special envoy, Robert Malley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Americans Have Discovered the Garden, and Celebrities Want In
description: Many of us turned to gardening for solace during the pandemic. Now Martha Stewart and Drew Barrymore want to guide us to green thumbs.
content: Last spring, as the world descended into a collective panic, Drew Barrymore planted her first lawn. “I did not think I could do this,” said Ms. Barrymore, 46, who until last year did not include gardening in her exhaustive list of achievements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Feeling a Bit Cramped? ‘Couples Therapy’ May Look Familiar
description: The Showtime docu-series lets viewers eavesdrop on real-life counseling sessions. The new season looks at relationships struggling under quarantine.
content: Tashira and her partner of three years, Dru, were curled up one night in Fall 2019, watching an episode of the first season of the Showtime documentary series “Couples Therapy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Justice Dept. Restores Use of Consent Decrees for Police Abuses
description: Attorney General Merrick Garland rescinded a Trump administration policy curbing use of the decrees, which provide a way to force changes in police departments.
content: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Merrick B. Garland on Friday rescinded a Trump administration policy that curbed the use of consent decrees to address police misconduct, as the Justice Department prepared to step up its role in investigating allegations of racist and illegal behavior by police forces amid a nationwide outcry about the deaths of Black people at the hands of officers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: These Leeks Are Anything but Humble
description: Yotam Ottolenghi cooks his leeks low and slow, in a bath of olive oil, until they’re magically tender and sweet.
content: LONDON — In my last column, I described how the past year had made me a more flexible cook: more democratic, less judgmental. It got me thinking generally about the way certain vegetables are described, the adjectives they are often associated with. Why is an eggplant deemed “mighty,” for example, while leeks are often prefaced with the word “humble”?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: wend
description: This word has appeared in 11 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr, Daniel Victor and Niraj Chokshi
title: The employees inside didn’t have cellphones, creating anguish for loved ones.
description: The policy is standard in industrial shipping and sorting facilities, to minimize worker distractions.
content: For family members agonizing over the fate of their loved ones who were working inside the FedEx facility where a shooting occurred late Thursday, the usual means of contacting them was cut off: Many did not have their cellphones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Myra Farooqi
title: I Tried to Filter Him Out
description: As a Pakistani Muslim, I knew that falling for a Hindu Indian would break me. And it did.
content: We started texting during the early months of the pandemic, going back and forth every day for hours. The stay-at-home order created a space for us to get to know each other because neither of us had any other plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Nijhuis
title: Plant a Love of Nature in Your Kids
description: This Earth Day, show kids they can find refuge in the outdoors.
content: Around 1954, when 8-year-old Stanley Temple began tagging along on Audubon Society field trips near Washington, D.C., he befriended a quiet, dark-haired woman who introduced herself as “Miss Carson.” To his delight, she treated him seriously as a fellow bird lover. “Most of the adult naturalists I knew wanted to teach me to identify things,” he said. “She taught me to stop and look.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Asparagus and books.
content: Want to get the At Home newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Simon & Schuster Says It Won’t Distribute Book by Officer Who Shot Breonna Taylor
description: Plans by Post Hill Press to publish the book, written by Sgt. Jonathan Mattingly, have drawn sharp criticism.
content: Simon & Schuster said late Thursday night that it had scrapped plans to distribute a book by one of the Louisville police officers who shot Breonna Taylor during the botched drug raid last year that resulted in her death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: The White House rejects calls for a gun ‘czar’ after the massacre in Indianapolis.
description: President Biden vows to “do more,” amid a wave of mass shootings that has left the administration with many questions, but few good options.
content: President Biden pledged to “do more” to address gun violence and implored Congress to act after a mass shooting in Indianapolis left eight people dead. But his administration, scrambling to respond to a new cycle of violence, rejected calls to appoint a gun “czar” to more forcefully confront the crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Shawn G. Kennedy, Times Reporter in a Vanguard, Dies at 73
description: She was part of a wave of recruited Black reporters who began changing the face of the paper in the ’70s. She also helped rebuild New Orleans after Katrina.
content: Back in the 1970s, as The New York Times lagged behind other papers in hiring reporters and editors of color, Paul Delaney, the first Black reporter hired in the newspaper’s Washington bureau, was among those helping to recruit nonwhite journalists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: SpaceX Wins NASA $2.9 Billion Contract to Build Moon Lander
description: Elon Musk’s company bested Jeff Bezos’ Blue Origin and others in the contest to carry American astronauts to the lunar surface.
content: Elon Musk’s private space company is developing a giant rocket called Starship to one day take people to Mars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: Unemployment Is High. Why Are Businesses Struggling to Hire?
description: Health concerns, expanded jobless benefits and still being needed at home are among the reasons would-be workers might be staying away.
content: There are two distinct, and completely opposite, ways of looking at the American job market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Mercedes unveils an electric version of its S-Class that goes farther than a Tesla.
description: The EQS has a range of 770 kilometers or about 480 miles, according to Mercedes. If that figure is confirmed, the EQS would dethrone the Tesla Model S Long Range Plus as the electric car with the longest range.
content: Mercedes-Benz unveiled an electric counterpart to its top-of-the-line S-Class sedan on Thursday, the latest in a series of moves by German automakers to defend their dominance of the high end of the car market against Tesla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: Weddings: He Followed His Heart to Memphis
description: Sarah Lockridge-Steckel moved to Memphis to start a nonprofit group. She was part of Kito Lord’s 10-year plan. So Memphis became part of his plan, too.
content: Dr. Kito Akin Obasi Lord likes to say he met Sarah Orcasita Lockridge-Steckel in January 2016 in Barcelona. Not the city in Spain, but a little restaurant-bar by that name near Yale in New Haven, Conn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Shirley Williams, Breakaway Political Force in Britain, Dies at 90
description: She was one of the “Gang of Four” who left Labour to start the more centrist Social Democratic Party in 1981, altering the country’s political landscape.
content: LONDON — Shirley Williams, a pioneering British lawmaker and former cabinet member who broke from the Labour Party in the 1980s to help found a centrist movement that briefly promised to upend British politics, died on Monday at her home in England. She was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timothy Egan
title: The Blue Wall of Silence Is Starting to Crack
description: Police say, ‘This is not who we are.’ Prove it.
content: I was driving around the other day when I realized that the license tabs on my car had expired. I didn’t panic, because I didn’t have to. If the cops pulled me over, I could feel assured as a white male: My life would not be in danger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Cavanagh
title: A New Line Inspired by Dancehall and Handicraft
description: The designer Rachel Scott has honed her skills at brands in Milan and New York, but when it came to creating her own label, Diotima, she looked homeward to Jamaica.
content: As a teen in 1990s Kingston, Jamaica, the fashion designer Rachel Scott was acutely aware of the tension between the decorum dictated by her Jesuit high school, where skirt lengths were checked on a regular basis, and the liberating dancehall scene she was swept up into at night. “There was this idea of being proper and having to present a certain way in the daytime — it was ridiculous,” says Scott, 37, speaking over Zoom from the lush green garden of her family’s house in Kingston, where she is visiting. But the soundtrack of her adolescence — the hip-swaying hits of local artists like Lady Saw, Shabba Ranks and Chaka Demus & Pliers that she heard at parties — left the more lasting impression. “Dancehall will forever be influential to me,” she says of the genre, which has roots in music of the African diaspora. “It’s like this explosion of exuberance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: White Police Officer to Face Charge She Intimidated Son’s Black Friend
description: Officer Patricia Lio of the Milton Police Department in Massachusetts is accused of berating her son’s 14-year-old Black friend about his stance on the Black Lives Matter movement.
content: A white Massachusetts police officer will face criminal charges in connection with an off-duty episode in which she is accused of berating a Black teenager, a friend of her son, over his support of the Black Lives Matter movement, a court official ruled this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Vegan Cheese, but Make It Delicious
description: Cheesemakers are pushing the boundaries of cultured, plant-based milks, producing more compelling vegan cheeses than ever before.
content: The pleasures of a bloomy-rind cheese begin before you slice into it — the softly wrinkled wheel, dappled and dimpled like the face of the moon. The promising stink, getting stronger by the minute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaux Laskey
title: Pasta Times Two
description: Sometimes, you just need a little more pasta: Pair it with garlicky spinach or feta and tomatoes.
content: Hi, everyone! Margaux Laskey here filling in for Emily this week. It’s a stunningly beautiful spring day where I am, like a Gerda Muller picture book come to life (except with sirens and aggressive pigeons). There’s a whisper of chill in the air, but the sun is bright, and I’m thinking this might be the weekend I plant pansies and begonias in my front porch pots. Maybe I won’t kill them this year. I am feeling hopeful about so many things. I wish that for you, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How a Legendary New York Hotel Became a Battleground
description: Mark Twain and Bob Dylan slept at the Chelsea. Now, developers hope to lure tourists, but they have to soothe some frustrated tenants.
content: You can’t exactly roam carefree through the Chelsea Hotel these days, re-enacting its bohemian past, open wine bottle in hand, say, while taking a break from writing your generation-defining novel, song, or Netflix script. Even if you found the drilling and hammering, dust and debris, and exposed cables and pipes inspirational, the Chelsea has not booked a guest room since 2011.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib
title: Raúl Castro to Step Down as Head of Cuba’s Communist Party
description: Mr. Castro said he will step down and pass on control of the party to Cuba’s younger generation. His departure will leave Cuba without a Castro at its helm for the first time in over 60 years.
content: MEXICO CITY — Raúl Castro announced Friday that he was handing over leadership of Cuba’s ruling Communist Party to a younger generation “full of passion and anti-imperialist spirit,” leaving the island nation without a Castro in a top leadership role for the first time in over 60 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: The Justice Department sues Roger Stone, a longtime Trump ally, alleging tax evasion.
description: Mr. Stone and his wife failed to pay almost $2 million in federal income taxes, the government said in its complaint, which also said they tried to hide their wealth in an investment entity.
content: The Justice Department filed a civil suit on Friday against Roger J. Stone, one of former President Donald J. Trump’s most visible allies, for failure to pay nearly $2 million in federal income taxes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Miller
title: How I Tricked Myself Into Liking Running
description: It’s good for your mental and physical health, and doesn’t require any equipment. So why does it seem so hard to get started?
content: Until last week, the only time I’d finished a race was during Track and Field Day in fifth grade. By middle school, I was trying to figure out how to get out of gym class because it was too hard for me to run a mile. Sports, in general, were not my thing. Running, less so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Sprinter’s Suspension Is Cut, but He’ll Still Miss the Olympics
description: Christian Coleman of the United States is the reigning world champion in the 100 meters and has never failed a drug test, but he missed three tests in 2019, resulting in an 18-month suspension.
content: Christian Coleman, the reigning world champion in the 100 meters, will miss the Tokyo Olympics this summer after the top judicial body in sport punished him with an 18-month ban from competition for missing three doping tests within a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christoph Koettl and Evan Hill
title: A Chase and a Fatal Split-Second Decision: How an Officer Killed Adam Toledo
description: In just under one second, the 13-year-old from Chicago appeared to toss away a handgun and turn with his hands raised before being shot.
content: Body camera footage released by an independent city agency in Chicago on Thursday showed Police Officer Eric E. Stillman fatally shoot 13-year-old Adam Toledo following an early-morning foot chase on March 29 on the city’s West Side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: $40,000 Swindle Puts Spotlight on Literary Prize Scams
description: The organizers of at least five British awards received emails asking them to transfer prize money to a PayPal account. One of them paid out.
content: LONDON — The organizers of the Baillie Gifford Prize, a respected British award for nonfiction writing, woke up on Nov. 25 to an excited email signed by the author Craig Brown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: He Flew From His Bike, and Later Fell Head Over Heels
description: Kaitlin Ruby Brinkerhoff met Ian McCann, a Canadian, on a mountain biking trip in her Utah hometown. They then maintained a challenging cross-border relationship through the pandemic.
content: Kaitlin Ruby Brinkerhoff and Ian McCann consider the two weeks spent quarantining in a freezing recreational vehicle in Canada last fall — she knitting afghans and he playing the video game Call of Duty — among the highlights of their relationship. They realize this may not be everybody’s idea of a good time, but for the cross-border couple, togetherness under any conditions felt magical.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Why Do We Let Corporations Profit From Rape Videos?
description: With help from Google, XVideos lets people leer at the worst moment in a child’s life.
content: This article contains descriptions of sexual assaults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Hong Kong Court Sentences Jimmy Lai and Other Pro-Democracy Leaders to Prison
description: The punishments for Mr. Lai, a media tycoon, and other leaders over an unauthorized peaceful protest point to what critics say is the shrinking space for dissent in Hong Kong.
content: HONG KONG — Jimmy Lai has skewered the Chinese Communist Party for decades. The 73-year-old founder of a fiercely pro-democracy newspaper in Hong Kong, Mr. Lai helped give voice to critics of the city’s leaders and their bosses in Beijing, winning friends in Washington and other places along the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Howard
title: How George Hahn, Urban Raconteur, Spends His Sundays
description: He is devoted to his dogs, his tiny apartment and most of all these days, his city.
content: George Hahn loves New York. But in 2016, the writer, actor and sartorial pragmatist wrote an essay about how the city — his home for 22 years — had become unsustainable for his creative lifestyle. He decided to move home, to Cleveland, Ohio, where he marveled at his 1,000-square-foot apartment (with in-suite washer/dryer). But he grew to miss New York terribly. So when a Manhattan dermatologist offered him a full-time job, he returned — in January 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: When Our Presses Rocked: A Music Video Starring a Beatle and The Times
description: Paul McCartney and the newspaper both make special appearances in Dominic Fike’s cover of “The Kiss of Venus.”
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Disappearing Slang and Cultural Variants: How Australian English Is Changing
description: Readers reflect on the country’s many different accents.
content: Last week, I wrote about whether an Asian-Australian accent existed and asked for your thoughts on how the Australian accent is changing. Dozens of readers wrote in about their experiences navigating regional, cultural and ethnic Australian accents, observing that the way we speak is becoming more homogenized, and to correct my own Australian linguistic error — yes, you’re right, we throw prawns, not shrimp, on the barbie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir and Michael Gold
title: Jurors in Daniel Prude Case Voted Overwhelmingly in Favor of Police
description: Mr. Prude’s death last year became part of a fraught national conversation around racism and brutality in policing.
content: Over the course of 45 hours, the grand jury convened in the case of Daniel Prude, a Black man who died after being detained by the police in Rochester, N.Y., last year, heard from more than 30 witnesses — including police officers, medical experts, a tow-truck driver and Mr. Prude’s brother, according to minutes of the proceedings released on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: S.U.V. Driver Jumps a Rising Drawbridge in Florida
description: The Daytona Beach Police Department said the jump, which was captured on video, was the second in the past few weeks.
content: As in a scene from a “Fast & Furious” spinoff, a driver in Florida this week jumped across a drawbridge just as its ramps were being raised.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Dazzling Skies, U.F.O. Sightings and Real-Life Monsters: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote the story.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Celebrating 15 Years of the Podcast
description: Pamela Paul, Sam Tanenhaus and others discuss what’s happened behind the scenes during 15 years of the podcast.
content: We’ve been in celebration mode all week as the Book Review’s podcast turns 15 years old. Pamela Paul shared 15 of her favorite episodes since she began hosting in 2013. We chose 10 other memorable conversations from the show’s full archives, and did a bit of digging to tell the story of the podcast’s earliest days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: After Years of Wrangling, World War I Memorial Raises First Flag
description: As the United States withdraws from its longest war, a memorial that recognizes one of its most complicated ones officially opened in Washington, D.C., on Friday.
content: WASHINGTON — Memorials to the war dead of the 20th century are among the central attractions in the nation’s capital. So it has always been notable that one of the most consequential American conflicts, World War I, lacked national recognition.
source.name: The New York Times

title: When a TikTok Influencer Dances, Who Gets Credit?
description: Addison Rae’s appearance on Jimmy Fallon’s show sparked conversations about appropriation and how dance has been central to the platform.
content: Late last month, the TikTok influencer Addison Rae went on “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon” and casually performed a suite of recent viral dance routines in a comedic skit. Critics reacted with cries of appropriation — the dances’ creators, many of them Black, were not credited — and with dismissals of Rae’s dancing ability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr and Mike Ives
title: What We Know About the Shooting in Indianapolis
description: Eight people were killed at a FedEx warehouse, the police said.
content: At least eight people died in a shooting at a FedEx facility in Indianapolis late Thursday, and the gunman was believed to have taken his own life, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Netflix to Debut Italy’s First TV Show With a Majority Black Cast
description: The creators of “Zero,” including the co-writer Antonio Dikele Distefano, say they hope viewers enjoy it so much that the characters’ racial identity becomes irrelevant.
content: ROME — While much of the world spent 2020 in lockdowns of varying severity, the 28-year-old Italian author Antonio Dikele Distefano had the busiest year of his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Trump is gone, but land disputes along the border continue under Biden.
description: After battling for years against the Trump administration’s plan to seize some of their family’s land in South Texas to build a border wall, the Cavazos siblings believed the inauguration of President Biden would bring a successful end to their fight.
content: After battling for years against the Trump administration’s plan to seize some of their family’s land in South Texas to build a border wall, the Cavazos siblings believed the inauguration of President Biden would bring a successful end to their fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zoë M. McLaren
title: Hang Out With Your Vaccinated Friends
description: Still waiting for your Covid-19 vaccine dose? Here’s one way to stay safe and keep cases down until your appointment.
content: The Covid-19 vaccines are a medical marvel. But many people are still waiting their turn to get vaccinated. Right now, with more infectious variants spreading and no authorized vaccine for children, the risks of Covid-19 to unvaccinated people remain high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marla Frazee
title: The Books That Led Her to Her Art
description: A children’s book illustrator and author describes her path through classics like “Blueberries for Sal” and “Where the Wild Things Are.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: How Democrats Who Lost in Deep-Red Places Might Have Helped Biden
description: A study by a liberal group found a reverse coattails effect in 2020: Down-ballot candidates may have helped elect President Biden, rather than the other way around.
content: Ebony Carter faced an uphill climb when she decided to run for the Georgia State Senate last year. Her deeply Republican district south of Atlanta had not elected a Democrat since 2001, and a Democrat hadn’t even bothered campaigning for the seat since 2014.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Lawrence Grant
title: What ‘Minnesota Nice’ Sweeps Under the Rug
description: The beloved stereotype about our state’s cult of politeness would have you believe that there’s no toehold for white supremacy here.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Minnesota has always imagined itself as someplace special, a place apart. This attitude has irked our neighbors in the Dakotas, Iowa and Wisconsin, and they have never suffered our swagger and hubris gladly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: A Wedding Date They’ll Remember. No Joke.
description: When Carla Kitzmiller and John Porter’s April 1 wedding seemed impossible to pull off, Ms. Kitzmiller’s co-workers helped to make it happen at the car dealership where she works.
content: In early March, Carla Kitzmiller, a title clerk at the Indiana car dealership Thomas Kia of Highland, went to work with a problem. She and her fiancé, John Porter, wanted to be married April 1, but because of Covid regulations, their options seemed limited to eloping at a courthouse near their home in Munster, Ind. “The girls I work with started talking, and they were like, ‘No! You can’t have family at the courthouse,’” Ms. Kitzmiller said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Is Fashion Hacking the Future? Gucci Says Yes.
description: And demonstrates with Balenciaga. Whatever you do, don’t use the word “collaboration.” Celine goes into the light.
content: Gucci is singing a brand-new tune. (Emphasis on “brand.” Or maybe “branded.”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert J. Shiller
title: Looking Back at the First Roaring Twenties
description: To understand where the stock market may be heading, a Nobel laureate examines the pop culture of one of the greatest bull markets in history.
content: We are in a second Roaring Twenties, or so you might think, from the countless comments suggesting that we are entering an exuberant decade that echoes the one of a century ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Shelia Smith, Exuberant Teacher’s Aide, Dies at 61
description: At her rural Alabama school, she was beloved by students, especially those with special needs, and by her colleagues. She died of complications of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gonchar and Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘A Tiny Particle’s Wobble Could Upend the Known Laws of Physics’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about muons and why scientists are carefully tracking how they spin inside a magnetic field. Are physicists on the verge of discovering new subatomic particles?
content: Featured Article: “A Tiny Particle’s Wobble Could Upend the Known Laws of Physics” by Dennis Overbye
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Twists and Turns of Black History
description: In different ways, three new books guide readers through the long struggle for equal rights.
content: UNTIL JUSTICE BE DONEAmerica’s First Civil Rights Movement, From the Revolution to ReconstructionBy Kate Masur480 pp. Norton. $32.

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Treasury Puts Taiwan on Notice in Currency Report but Strikes Measured Tone
description: The Biden administration removed Vietnam and Switzerland from the list of currency manipulators, but it will push all three countries to address its concerns.
content: The Treasury Department said on Friday that it was putting Taiwan, Vietnam and Switzerland on notice over their currency practices, but it struck a more conciliatory tone than the Trump administration by stopping short of labeling any of them a currency manipulator.
source.name: The New York Times

content: I have spent the past two weeks reading about the infrastructure debate with mounting rage. When a reporter asked me recently why I felt so strongly, I sputtered, groping for the words. Ultimately, however, the answer is simple. Insisting that there is actually a fixed definition of what infrastructure is — bridges, but not baby care — perfectly encapsulates the ways in which the world is still shaped by men. Not just conservative men, but men across the political spectrum. Men today, that is: Three-quarters of a century ago, the Greatest Generation recognized that both forms of infrastructure were essential to the war effort.

Five years later Freya, now 23, travels to Bligh from London for a wedding reception at Byrne Hall, only to discover a portrait of Stella hanging on a wall. title: Corrections: April 16, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, April 16, 2021.
content: An article on Thursday about Coinbase’s stock market arrival misspelled the name of a blockchain platform. It is Ethereum, not Ethererum. The article also may have implied incorrectly that Bitcoin is likely to shift to a proof-of-stake model. While some critics say Bitcoin will eventually need to make the switch, there are no plans to do so, and the idea is broadly unpopular within the Bitcoin community.
